title: A protocol to inject ocular drug implants into mouse eyes
procedures:
Step-by-step method details
Step-by-step method details
This section provides detailed instructions for injecting an implant by using air-pressure based microinjector (part 2a) and injecting an implant by using a plunger (part 2b). Based on the physical properties of the implants (size, weight, density, and surface property), either an air-pressure based microinjector or a plunger can be used. The air-pressure based microinjector method (part 2a) is easier to use than the plunger-based method, but smaller, lighter, and/or less surface-resistant implants are preferred. The plunger-based method (part 2b) is less restricted by the physical properties of the implants. For experienced users, we recommend testing the air-pressure based microinjector method (part 2a) first due to the simple surgical setup and straightforward procedure.
Part 1. Rodent handling
Timing: 30 min
The mouse was anesthetized using ketamine and xylazine based on its body weight according to the Administrative Panel of Laboratory Animal Care (APLAC) and the Institutional Animal Care and Use Committee (IACUC)-approved protocols at Stanford University.
Weigh the animal and calculate the correct dosage of the ketamine and xylazine injection mixture.
Note: 0.08 mg ketamine/g and 0.01 mg xylazine/g
Using one hand, restrain the mouse with the abdomen facing up.
Perform the intraperitoneal injection with the ketamine and xylazine mixture using a 20 G needle.
Place the mouse on the heating pad.
Apply 1% tropicamide to dilate the pupil.
Trim the whiskers to prevent microscope examination disruption (Figure 5[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig5]; left panel).
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/1406-Fig5.jpg
Figure 5. Mouse preparation for the implant surgery
The whiskers and the hairs may interfere with the implant injection procedure by blocking the eye. Mouse whiskers are trimmed using scissors (left panel). The coat around the mouse eye is wetted to keep fur together and away from the eyeball (middle panel). An injection ready mouse is presented (right panel).

Wet around the eye with clean 1X PBS (Figure 5[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig5]; middle panel).
Wait for 5 min for the mouse to become anesthetized (Figure 5[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig5]; right panel).
Apply lubricant eye drops to the eye to prevent the cornea surface from drying out.
Note: Apply one drop per eye every 5 min.
Part 2a. Implant injection by air-pressure
Timing: 10 min for each surgery
To inject an implant by air-pressure, an electronic microinjector commonly used for intravitreal injection of fluids was utilized. The following is the step-by-step procedure for the electronic microinjector setup, the surgery bed setup, and the surgical process for an implant injection by air-pressure:
The electronic microinjector setup.
Turn on the electronic microinjector and run a self-test.
Assemble the needle with the capillary holder and positioning aids (Figures 6[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig6]A and 6B).
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/1406-Fig6.jpg
Figure 6. Setup for microinjector-based implant injection
(A) Electronic microinjector compartments. A positioning aid loaded with an injection needle (injection module) and an injection pedal are connected to an electronic microinjector. By pressing the injection pedal, the electronic microinjector will send compressed air to the needle through the injection module.
(B) Compartments of the injection module and their assembly are shown.
(C) Overview of the microinjector method surgery platform. A mouse and heating pad are set under the dissecting microscope, and the injection module is attached to the electronic microinjector and the injection pedal is placed near the microscope.
Connect the injection device to the electronic microinjector.
Set up a working parameter for the electronic microinjector: 500 hPa injection pressure, 1.0 s injection time.
Surgery bed setup (Figure 6[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig6]C).
Set a heating pad on the surgery bed to maintain the body temperature of the mouse.
Note: The preset of the heating pad used was 37°C.
Transfer an anesthetized animal to the surgery bed for surgery.

Apply lubricant eye drops to the eyes to prevent the cornea surface from drying out.
Implant injection.
Sterilize the needle and capillary holder with 70% ethanol.
Load the needle to a capillary holder attached to a positioning aid.
Hold and adjust the animal’s head using the non-dominant hand, and perform the injection using the dominant-hand.
Gently insert the needle into the eyeball.
Note: The recommended needle entry-position is 2 mm posterior to the limbus (troubleshooting 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec7.7]) in order to reach the vitreous cavity directly with minimal possible damage to the lens, central retina, or optic nerve.
Note: The needle is perpendicular to the eye surface.
Note: The recommended depth of the needle head is 2–3 mm.
Press the foot control pedal to engage the electronic microinjector.
Once the implant is delivered, slowly remove the needle from the eyeball.
Apply the antibiotic ophthalmic solution to the eye to prevent potential infections.
Place the post-surgical mouse on a heating pad until it wakes up.
Note: Throughout the procedure, keep applying one lubricant eye drop every 5 min to prevent the cornea surface from drying out.
Part 2b. Implant injection by plunger
Timing: 50 min for surgery tool production/10 min for each surgery
To inject an implant by plunger, a micromanipulator and a syringe-cleaning wire were utilized. The following is the step-by-step procedure to make the plunger, assemble the injection module, and set up the micromanipulator and the surgery bed. The surgical process for an implant injection by plunger is also detailed:

Implant plunger making. To generate an implant plunger, a syringe cleaning wire was used. To adjust the thickness of the implant plunger to fit into the needle, one end of the syringe cleaning wire was ground using a Black Arkansas stone until the diameter of the wire was 50 μm. The following is the step-by-step procedure for making the implant plunger:
Apply a syringe-cleaning wire on the Black Arkansas stone.
Using your pointer finger, press and move one end of the cleaning wire back and forth.
After 10 repetitions, check the width under a dissecting microscope.
Repeat step c. until the diameter of the wire reaches 50 μm (Figure 7[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig7]A).
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/1406-Fig7.jpg
Figure 7. Tools and surgery platform setup for plunger-based implant injection
(A) Implant plunger before sharpening (left panel) and after sharpening (right panel).
(B) Injection module before (left panel) and after (right panel) sharpening and assembly.
(C) Injection module mounted on micromanipulator, with needle at 30° angle (magenta). Plunging-end hole is available for plunger loading and manipulation.
(D) Overview of the plunger method surgery platform. A mouse and heating pad are set under the dissecting microscope, and the micromanipulator is placed nearby to be seen under the microscope.
(E) Overview of the plunger-based method surgery platform. A mouse and heating pad are set under the dissecting microscope, and the micromanipulator with assembled plunger-module placed near the microscope.
Optional: By banding the non-ground end of the cleaning wire, make a handle-like structure that can be used to easily manipulate the plunger during surgery.
Injection module assembly. An injection module was assembled to mount the implant loaded needle to the micromanipulator (Figure 7[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig7]B). The following is the step-by-step procedure for the injection module assembly:
Sterilize the needle and capillary holder with 70% ethanol.

Assemble the implant loaded needle to a capillary holder.
Note: This step should be done with care so that the implant does not fall out of the needle.
Note: Parafilm the needle and the capillary holder together to provide a more stable assembly.
Insert the plunger into the hole at the opposite end of the needle tip.
Keep the plunger at the halfway point of the implant loaded needle.
Note: The plunger should not be touching the implant.
Micromanipulator and surgery bed setup. For the intravitreal injection, stability of the microcapillary during the surgery is very important. Since the mouse eye is small and fragile, any unnecessary movement or vibration from the surgical hand may damage or tear the eyeball during injection. There are several commercially available micromanipulators with angle specific adjustable arms. In our MI3 method, utilizing a micromanipulator provides a precise and stable position to fine-tune the needle holder angle. Also, it secures the needle position and supports a smooth injection when using the plunger. The following is the recommended setup for the micromanipulator and the surgical platform for the intravitreal injection of ODIs:
Install the micromanipulator right next to the animal surgical platform.
Set the angle of the needle holder on the micromanipulator to 30°.
Raise the surgical bed to meet the height limitation of the micromanipulator.
Place the heating pad on top of the surgical bed.
Set the heat to maintain the body temperature of the mouse.
Note: The preset of the heating pad used was 37°C.
Place the implant and plunger loaded needle on the micromanipulator (Figures 7[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig7]C and 7D).
Adjust the micromanipulator location, making the needle and eye visible under the dissecting microscope’s examination stage (Figure 7[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig7]E).
Implant injection (Methods video S1[href=https://www.wicell.org#mmc2]).

Using the micromanipulator’s x-axis adjustment knob, move the needle closer to the injection site.
Apply lubricant eye drops to the eye to prevent the eye from drying.
Slowly adjust the x-axis adjustment knob until the needle is inserted into the eye.
Note: The recommended needle entry-position is 2 mm posterior to the limbus (troubleshooting 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec7.7]).
Insert the needle until the tip of the needle can be seen in the eye under the dissecting microscope.
Note: The recommended depth of the needle head is 2–3 mm.
Move the plunger from the bottom of the microcapillary until its end touches the implant (troubleshooting 5[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec7.9]).
Gently push the implant into the eye.
When the implant is fully inserted, slowly remove the needle by adjusting the x-axis adjustment knob.
Apply an antibiotic ophthalmic solution to the eye to prevent potential infections.
Place the post-surgical mouse on a heating pad until it wakes up.
Note: Throughout the procedure, keep applying one lubricant eye drop every 5 min to prevent the cornea surface from drying out.
